page.title: 05WOOLHOPE ECOLOGY (1)
page.content: {Conservation Many farms have small wooded areas, ditches & hedgerows which are sites for many wild flowers. In springtime wild daffodils & bluebells are a beautiful sight. Woodlands are generally mixed deciduous & coniferous. In 1985 Hereford Botanical Society is surveying the local flora. {Broadmoor Common }35 acres now belongs to Hereford C.C. & is registered as common land, used for grazing. There are five distinct habitats, unimproved grassland, marsh, dense gorse and bramble thickets, woodland & neglected hedgerow with oak, birch, willow & hawthorn. Nightingales still breed here. Woodcock & mallard are seen. One pond contains three species of newt. { }
